subject: Re: [junit] Re: class isolation and class order for testing

messageBody:
On 15/01/2008, Chris Dollin <chris.dollin@...> wrote:
> On Tuesday 15 January 2008 09:47, csabcsi.szucs wrote:
>
> > I meant the following:
> > I cannot do a TDD this time, because I have already an existing
> > project with about 100 production classes (and some time to learn and
> > exercise JUnit tests).
>
> Read Michael Feathers' book /Working Effectively with Legacy Code/.
>
> > So which class shall I start with to write JUnit tests for? Perhaps
> > it is worth starting with a class that does not have any collaborators
> > or only ones that are already tested in a previous "test phase".
>
> I'd suggest classes which are likely to be worked on "soon". Those are,
> after all, the ones which you might otherwise break, and for which
> unit tests will add most value.
>
> It's tempting to start with "easy" ones, but you run the risk of writing
> tests for things that won't change and won't break, and you'd gain an
> unrealistic view of how easy it is(n't) to add tests post-hoc.

All good advice.

I'd also cover the code with end-to-end tests.

Unit tests give you a lot of feedback about the internal quality of
your code (is it maintainable, readable, decoupled, cohesive etc.),
but less feedback about the external quality of the code (is it good
enough for purpose).

End-to-end and integration tests give you more feedback about the
external quality of your code, but less feedback about its internal
quality. E.g. the tell you whether all the pieces work together, but
not whether the pieces are well structured and easily (un)pluggable.

If you've already got a lot of code, feedback about its internal
quality now is a bit late in the day. I expect you're concerned about
regressions as you add behaviour. So, I would concentrate on
integration and end-to-end tests to ensure correct system behaviour.

It's worth adding unit tests for new classes as you add new behaviour.
They will also help you to discover where the code is difficult to
maintain and help you introduce flex points. At that point you can
start refactoring the existing code, where it touches the new code, to
make it more testable and more easily surround the refactored with
unit tests. You'll feel more confident that you aren't breaking
anything because the end-to-end tests will help detect any regressions
the changes cause.

--Nat
